msIdentifier.repository: National Archives and Records Administration, Seattle Branch, Washington
msIdentifier.collection: RG 21 US District Court Western Division of Washington, Seattle

div1.p: In the Supreme Court of the District of Columbia.
In the Matter of Ching Hing

After reading and filing such part of the petition for Writ of Habeas Corpus as raised the issue before the Court, which petition was verified Septmeber 29th, 1914 by John J. Sullivan, Esq., attorney for one Ching Hing and filed in the District Court of the United States for the Western District of Washington, Northern Division, on the same date; and the order of the honorable Jeremiah Neterer, Judge of aforesaid Court, dated October 20, 194, commissioning Thomas G. Lewis, Esq., to take the testimony in Washington, D.C., of Louis F. Post, Assistant Secretary of Labor and others in the matter of said Ching Hing on his petition for release from custody; and the order of said Honorable Judge settling and referring to certain agreed questions to be propounded to said Louis F. Postby the said Commissioner Lewis; and the said questions, and stipulation between Counsel for the United States, Honorable George P. Fishburn, Assistant District Attorney, and Messrs. Beeler and Sullivan for the said Ching Hing, agreeing that such questions should be propounded to said Louis F. Post, Assistant Secretary of Labor, as foresaid: and after reading the return of the U. S. Marshall for the District of Columbia that he had duly and legally served said Post with subpoena legally and reularly issued out of this Court by the Clerk hereof in accordance with Section 868 of the RevisedStatutes of the United States (Act of Jan. 24, 1827, ch. 4, 4 Stat. L 197) to appear before said Lewis on the eleventh day of November, 1914 at three o'clock p. m.and the certifiate and affidavit of said Lewis that said Post had duy appeared on the day specified in said subpoeana and the said questions had been duly propounded to him and the same held by the said Lewis to be proper and relevant to the issue before the Honorable Judge of the District Court of the United States for the Western District of Washington, aforesaid and necessar to be responded to fully and thruthfully in order to enable said Honerable Judge to determine the issue before him in said case of Ching Hing aforesaid, which the petition for the Writ of habeas Corpus aforesaid shows to be material; and said certificate and addidavit of said Lewis showing that said Post wilfully refused to answer said questions so stipulated to be propounded, so settled by said Judge of the United States District Court aforesaid, and so held to be relevant by said Commissioner Lewis, said Pos refusing to answer the same because he claimed the information which they sought to bring forth was privileged; and on reading and filing the order for said Post to show cuase herein why an order should not be entered in acordance with Section 868 of the Revised Statutes of the United States (4 Stat. L. 197) directing him to answer the questions as aforesaid; and the return of said Post thereto, verified November 20, 1914; and after hearing Corry M. Stadden, Esq., attorney for said Commissioner Lewi in behalf of said motion, and Hon. James B. Archer, Assistant U. S. Attorney for the District of Columbia in behalf of Louis F. Post; and after due consideration had, it is this 10th day of June, 1915

Ordered: That the said Louis F. Post be and he hearby is directed and commaned to appear before the said Thomas G. Lewis, Commissioner fuly appointed by the United States District Court of the Western District of Washington, Northern Division, at the office of said Commissioner in the Commercial National Bank Building, No. 708 Fourteenth St., N.W, on the 23rd10th day of FebruaryJune, 1915, at three o'clock in the afternoon of said day, or as soon thereafter as said Commissiner can hear him, and full and true response make to the following question: "Were you on duty at the Department of Labor on each of the following dates: September 24th, 1914, September 25th,191, and September 26th, 1914?"

p.add: Form satisfactory James B. Archer Assistant U. S. Atty
